newsitem.title: CHINA: China's seven-year bond makes poor debut.
newsitem.headline: China's seven-year bond makes poor debut.

text.p: China's first seven-year treasury bond made a disappointing debut on the Shanghai stock exchange on Thursday, becoming the first T-bond this year to trade below its issue price of 100 yuan.
The bond opened at 99.90 yuan and soon hit an intra-day low of 98.53 yuan before recovering slightly. It ended at 98.60 yuan, after hitting a high of 99.99 yuan.

Traders said the bond, bearing a higher coupon than bank interest rates, had been hurt by Beijing's demand for tighter liquidity with the approach of the year-end and a bull run on China's stock markets.

The People's Bank of China, the central bank, has instructed state banks and financial institutions to maintain tight money supply with the approach of the year-end, which has reduced liquidity flowing into the T-bond spot market, they said.
The bond, the last issue of China's state debt this year, has a coupon of 8.56 percent, 1.09 percentage points higher than the annual rate of 7.47 percent for one-year bank deposits.
A total of 20 billion yuan worth of the seven-year T-bond was issued from November 1 to Wednesday, bringing total T-bill and T-bond issues in China this year to a record 220 billion yuan.
But traders said that, after Thursday's fall, the room for further losses would be limited due to the bond's high returns.
